articles.headline: Puerto Rico Spent 11 Months Turning the Power Back On. They Finally Got to Her.
articles.snippet: The problem-plagued effort to restore electric service after the storm blacked out the whole island last year is finally reaching the last few darkened homes, officials say.
articles.abstract: The problem-plagued effort to restore electric service after the storm blacked out the whole island last year is finally reaching the last few darkened homes, officials say.
articles.lead_paragraph: PONCE, P.R. — Jazmín Méndez has lived much of the last year in the dark. No light to read by. No food cooled in the fridge. No television for her three children.

articles.headline: Kavanaugh Could Unlock Funding for Religious Education, School Voucher Advocates Say
articles.snippet: Brett M. Kavanaugh’s confirmation to the Supreme Court could advance efforts to make publicly funded vouchers available to students attending religious schools.
articles.abstract: Brett M. Kavanaugh’s confirmation to the Supreme Court could advance efforts to make publicly funded vouchers available to students attending religious schools.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh, in a speech last year, gave a strong hint at his views on taxpayer support for religious schools when he praised his “first judicial hero,” Justice William Rehnquist, for determining that the strict wall between church and state “was wrong as a matter of law and history.”

articles.headline: $100 Million Was Once Big Money for a Start-Up. Now, It’s Common.
articles.snippet: Known as a mega-round in Silicon Valley, large-scale fund raising is producing a frenzy around tech companies with enough reach and momentum to absorb a large check.
articles.abstract: Known as a mega-round in Silicon Valley, large-scale fund raising is producing a frenzy around tech companies with enough reach and momentum to absorb a large check.
articles.lead_paragraph: In late April, when Mike Massaro set out to get $40 million to $75 million in funding for his payments start-up, Flywire, he contacted a small group of investors he already knew. But word quickly got around, and other investors flooded his inbox with $200 million of investment offers, half of which he turned down.

articles.headline: Catholic Priests Abused 1,000 Children in Pennsylvania, Report Says
articles.snippet: The grand jury report is the government’s broadest look yet in the United States at child sexual abuse in the church.
articles.abstract: The grand jury report is the government’s broadest look yet in the United States at child sexual abuse in the church.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bishops and other leaders of the Roman Catholic Church in Pennsylvania covered up child sexual abuse by more than 300 priests over a period of 70 years, persuading victims not to report the abuse and law enforcement not to investigate it, according to a searing report issued by a grand jury on Tuesday.
articles.byline: By Laurie Goodstein and Sharon Otterman

articles.headline: Turks Scramble as Lira Falls and Prices Soar
articles.snippet: Some businesses have doubled prices on imported goods this year and are already feeling a falloff in sales, as economists warn of galloping inflation.
articles.abstract: Some businesses have doubled prices on imported goods this year and are already feeling a falloff in sales, as economists warn of galloping inflation.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Prices have soared on imported goods, scaring buyers and sellers. Sales are off as Turks delay purchases or cut back. Everyone is quoting the exchange rate, feverishly calculating what to do with his or her savings, large and small, and watching the price of goods daily.

articles.headline: How a Fake Group on Facebook Created Real Protests
articles.snippet: The Black Elevation page held rallies, posted videos and encouraged the fight against racism. Whoever ran it even interviewed a job applicant.
articles.abstract: The Black Elevation page held rallies, posted videos and encouraged the fight against racism. Whoever ran it even interviewed a job applicant.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Black Elevation appeared to be an organization dedicated to fighting racism to the tens of thousands of people who visited its page on Facebook.

articles.headline: Tesla Directors, in Damage Control Mode, Want Elon Musk to Stop Tweeting
articles.snippet: Tesla’s board of directors has hired multiple outside law firms, and a number of board members and Tesla employees have urged Mr. Musk to stop posting on Twitter.
articles.abstract: Tesla’s board of directors has hired multiple outside law firms, and a number of board members and Tesla employees have urged Mr. Musk to stop posting on Twitter.
articles.lead_paragraph: Members of Tesla’s board are scrambling to control a chief executive who some directors think is out of control.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jessica Silver-Greenberg, Kate Kelly and Neal E. Boudette

articles.headline: French Labor Overhaul Led by Unusual Figure: A Business Executive
articles.snippet: Muriel Pénicaud has one of the toughest jobs around: overseeing a revamp of France’s voluminous labor code.
articles.abstract: Muriel Pénicaud has one of the toughest jobs around: overseeing a revamp of France’s voluminous labor code.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Muriel Pénicaud is the sort of figure that French protesters love to bash. A former human resources executive. A tenacious negotiator who wrangles with unions. And a friend to business leaders and political elites.

articles.headline: Hungary’s Leader Was Shunned by Obama, but Has a Friend in Trump
articles.snippet: Prime Minister Viktor Orban joins a growing roster of right-wing or euroskeptic leaders in Europe to have secured President Trump’s backing.
articles.abstract: Prime Minister Viktor Orban joins a growing roster of right-wing or euroskeptic leaders in Europe to have secured President Trump’s backing.
articles.lead_paragraph: BUDAPEST — Across rural Hungary, Prime Minister Viktor Orban dominates the media landscape. His allies control the major regional newspapers, which provide supportive coverage of Mr. Orban’s anti-immigrant agenda and his methodical erosion of the country’s democratic checks and balances. Critical, independent outlets are mostly absent.

articles.headline: Should Coffee Come With Cancer Warnings? California Says No
articles.snippet: Amid concerns that consumers face too many warnings, a California agency is moving to nullify a judge’s ruling that coffee be accompanied with a cancer notice.
articles.abstract: Amid concerns that consumers face too many warnings, a California agency is moving to nullify a judge’s ruling that coffee be accompanied with a cancer notice.
articles.lead_paragraph: In every cup of coffee, there is a chemical linked to cancer.

articles.headline: Democrats Discard Washington Platform in Bid for House Control
articles.snippet: Unlike 1994 and its “Contract With America” or 2006 and its “Six for ’06,” this midterm campaign will not feature a centralized message from the party seeking control of the House.
articles.abstract: Unlike 1994 and its “Contract With America” or 2006 and its “Six for ’06,” this midterm campaign will not feature a centralized message from the party seeking control of the House.
articles.lead_paragraph: DALLAS — House Democrats, looking to wrest control of the chamber from Republicans in November, are discarding the lessons of successful midterms past and pressing only a bare-bones national agenda, leaving it to candidates to tailor their own messages to their districts.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Nicholas Fandos

articles.headline: Italy Bridge Was Known to Be in Trouble Long Before Collapse
articles.snippet: As the death toll climbed in Genoa, signs pointed to failure in the design and maintenance of the Morandi Bridge.
articles.abstract: As the death toll climbed in Genoa, signs pointed to failure in the design and maintenance of the Morandi Bridge.
articles.lead_paragraph: GENOA, Italy — As deaths from the  bridge failure in Genoa rose on Wednesday to 39, it became clear that while the collapse was catastrophic, it was not exactly a surprise.
articles.byline: By Gaia Pianigiani, Elisabetta Povoledo and Richard Pérez-Peña
